channel.title: CNN.com - World
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - World
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: $40 helps family break free of abuse
item.description: Johanna Crawford was volunteering for a domestic violence shelter in 2003 when she answered a hot line call she will never forget.

item.title: Know a hero? Nominate them!
item.description: Do you know an everyday person changing the world? It's easy to nominate them as a CNN Hero.

item.title: 'Kliptown' kids reclaim their future
item.description: Brian Munyai has spent nearly all of his 22 years living in a one-room shack that has never had electricity or running water.

item.title: After tragic visit, officer says 'enough'
item.description: Shortly after joining the Lake Mary Police Department in 2007, Zach Hudson was dispatched to the home of two elderly women.

item.title: An answer to grannies' cries for help
item.description: Jackson Kaguri escaped poverty, earned a college degree and was living the American dream. But when he went back to his old village in Uganda, he realized he had to do something.

item.title: Dad gives teens money not to drink
item.description: Five years ago, Leo McCarthy lost his 14-year-old daughter, Mariah, when a drunken driver hit her and two of her friends as they walked down a sidewalk near her home. But he refused to let her tragic death become just another statistic.

item.title: War vets find peace at end of leash
item.description: A trip to the grocery store used to send James McQuoid into a panic. When the Iraq War veteran heard a child crying, he would remember kids screaming in Fallujah. But things are getting better now that he has Iggie by his side.

item.title: Back-to-back typhoons hit China
item.description: Two tropical cyclones have made landfall in eastern China, prompting the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of people from coastal areas as the Philippines and Taiwan assess the damage that one of the storms left in its wake.

item.title: Israeli sets himself on fire
item.description: A wheelchair-bound Israeli veteran died Wednesday, days after setting himself on fire in a protest over his economic situation, a spokeswoman for Sheba Medical Center in Tel Aviv said.

item.title: Typhoon kills 23 in Philippines
item.description: Heavy rains from the outer bands of Typhoon Saola, which hovered near the Philippines beginning last week, have left 23 people dead and another five injured, an official with the National Disaster Coordinating Center said Thursday.

item.title: '$1T' fuel subsidies sparks debate
item.description: Political consensus was hard to find at last month's Rio +20 Earth Summit but there was at least one group speaking with unity on the planet's environmental and economic future.

item.title: Has the electric car found its range?
item.description: Despite their green credentials, electric cars still come up short against their petrol-powered cousins when it comes to range -- how far they go before the battery needs recharging.

item.title: 'Crate home' thinks outside the box
item.description: Living in a house made from shipping containers isn't exactly everyone's idea of a dream home.

item.title: Paris' Empire of the Dead
item.description: Beneath the streets of the City of Light lies a world draped in darkness and shrouded in silence. The tunnels are narrow, the ceilings are low and death is on display.

item.title: Veiled TV: Progress or step back?
item.description: After graduating from the mass communication department of Cairo University, Heba Seraq-Eddin couldn't find a job. Potential employers turned her down, she says, because of her veil. Heba wears the niqab, the black fabric that covers her whole face, except for the eyes.

item.title: Judge: Namibians sterilized
item.description: A judge ruled Monday that three HIV-positive women in Namibia were sterilized without their informed consent, their lawyer said.

item.title: Barak on Bulgaria attack
item.description: Israeli Defense Minister Ehud Barak says Israel will seek retribution for Bulgaria attack and refers to '72 Munich Olympics massacre.

item.title: Noah's Ark replica
item.description: A Dutchman has built a replica of Noah's Ark to biblical proportions, following a dream his homeland would be flooded.

item.title: Japan grapples with teen bullies
item.description: Incense burns in the corner of the Nakai family living room -- part of an altar to their daughter Yumi, who committed suicide seven years ago. Yumi was just 12 years old when she took her own life, jumping from a condominium building.

item.title: Olympics: Medals, money and more
item.description: As the 2012 Summer Games begin, check out the medals, the money and which four nations have competed in every Summer Olympics.

item.title: London in time-lapse
item.description: Watch a time lapse film of how a run-down area was transformed into an Olympic arena ahead of the grand opening ceremony.

item.title: Spa offers 'snake massage'
item.description: A Moscow spa uses snakes as part of its exotic massage service.

item.title: Kim Jong Un, wife at amusement park
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and his wife take in attractions at a local amusement park. State media reports.

item.title: Horror inside Mali refugee camp
item.description: CNN's Erin Burnett goes inside a refugee camp in Mali which houses people who have fled Islamic militants.

item.title: Dramatic rescue of wedding party
item.description: A wedding caravan fell 30 feet into a river after a bridge collapsed in China.

item.title: America and its gun history
item.description: What is it about Americans and guns?

item.title: Africa's 'bombs and bullets' myth
item.description: Africa is poor, corrupt and rural. Right? Think again. A team of young documentary makers is hoping to burst the myth of Africa as a dangerous backwater by shining a light on some inspiring projects taking place on the continent.

item.title: U.S. sending cows to Kazakhstan
item.description: Kazakhstan is building a new industry in cattle farming with outside help. CNN's Frederik Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Norway massacre, 1 year later
item.description: A year after Anders Behring Breivik killed 77 people in a bomb and gun rampage in Norway, Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg urged Norwegians to "honor the dead by celebrating life."

item.title: First Bollywood superstar dies
item.description: The Indian actor Rajesh Khanna, who became the first Bollywood superstar, died Wednesday in Mumbai at the age of 69, his family said.

item.title: From Arab Spring to Olympics
item.description: Before the light, the dark.

item.title: Canine cops to carry cameras
item.description: They've long been man's best friend, but now dogs with one British police force can hound criminals in a new way thanks to "FidoCam," a digital video camera that straps to the canine's head.

item.title: Happy birthday, Nelson Mandela
item.description: South Africans celebrated Nelson Mandela's 94th birthday Wednesday by participating in good deeds nationwide to honor the legacy of the famous statesman.

item.title: Syrian blogger: 'I live or die here'
item.description: Twenty-something "Al" has a life interrupted, days and nights existing in two states: mundane, almost zombie-like boredom and run-for-your life terror

item.title: Quiz: Could you park a plane?
item.description: Every day 1,300 aircraft pass through London's Heathrow Airport. Making sure all those planes are in the right place at the right time is the job of the aircraft marshal.

item.title: Writer's week living at Heathrow
item.description: Heathrow Airport is under close scrutiny over how it will cope with the influx of travelers for the London Olympics, but at least it has one fan in British writer Tony Parsons.

item.title: Heathrow ready for the Olympics?
item.description: Becky Anderson visits Heathrow's multi-million dollar Games Terminal that will host 80% of travel during the Olympics

item.title: Acid and poison hinder schooling
item.description: Terrorists will stop at nothing to keep Afghan girls from receiving an education.

item.title: Shedding light on 'dirty war'
item.description: After years of trying to put the past behind it, Brazil has created a truth commission to investigate crimes committed during a painful period in history known as the dirty war.

item.title: Inventor of Web: What Web, Olympics have in common
item.description: The founder of the World Wide Web may not be the world's most prolific micro-blogger -- but Tim Berners-Lee's "This is for everyone" tweet at the Olympic opening ceremony set the tone for what has been dubbed the first "social media Games."

item.title: How to give an elephant a pedicure
item.description: From elephants getting pedicures to hipsters holding their own Olympics, here's a look at some recent stories from CNN's affiliates around the world that are interesting, unique or just plain bizarre.

item.title: Q&A: What options are left in Syria?
item.description: What options are left for U.S. in Syria, what can the U.N. do now and what's on the horizon in Aleppo and Damascus? Check out the Q&A.

item.title: Dodging acid, poison to go to school
item.description: Terrorists will stop at nothing to keep Afghan girls from receiving an education.

item.title: Solutions by world's richest man
item.description: World's richest man Carlos Slim talks to CNN about the Euro debt crisis and the growth outlook for Latin America

item.title: Couple stoned to death for adultery
item.description: Islamists in control of northern Mali said they forced a man and a woman into two holes and stoned them to death for committing adultery in the lawless region.

item.title: Shedding light on 'dirty war' abuses
item.description: After years of trying to put the past behind it, Brazil has created a truth commission to investigate crimes committed during a painful period in history known as the dirty war.

item.title: Tropical Storm Ernesto breezes past Jamaica; Florence weakens
item.description: Tropical Storm Ernesto churned south of Jamaica on Sunday, becoming a bit more organized as it continued its westward march.

item.title: Exotic breeds freed from Tasmania zoo
item.description: Dozens of animals, some of them rare, remained missing from Tasmania's only accredited zoo Saturday, two days after someone released the creatures into the wild, the zoo's co-owner said.

item.title: British court convicts parents in 'honor' murder
item.description: The parents of a 17-year-old girl will spend at least 25 years in a British prison for the death of their daughter after the couple's conviction Friday for killing her over her desire to live a Westernized lifestyle and become an attorney, a court spokeswoman said Friday.

item.title: Could Ebola outbreak spread to U.S.?
item.description: Fourteen people have died so far from the Ebola outbreak that began earlier this month in Western Uganda. According to the World Health Organization, the first case is believed to be from the Nyanswiga village in Nyamarunda, a sub-county of the Kibaale district of Uganda.

item.title: North Koreans in desperate need of food after floods
item.description: The World Food Programme said Friday it is stepping in to feed people in North Korea, where floods have ruined crops and left nearly 63,000 homeless, according to reports.

item.title: Judge in Spain takes statements from terror suspects
item.description: A judge at the Spanish National Court took statements Friday from three men who may have been plotting terrorist attacks on British and U.S. targets, an Interior Ministry spokeswoman said.

item.title: Brazil's 'trial of the century' begins
item.description: Seven years after politicians were accused in a vote-buying scheme, Brazil's Supreme Court on Thursday started the trial of 38 people suspected of involvement in the scandal.

item.title: Couple stoned to death for adultery
item.description: Islamists in control of northern Mali said they forced a man and a woman into two holes and stoned them to death for committing adultery in the lawless region.

item.title: Murder trial this week for Chinese politician's wife
item.description: The wife of a former Communist Party leader will go on trial next week in the alleged killing of a British businessman, a friend of the suspect's family said Friday.

item.title: London Olympics by the numbers
item.description: The Olympic Games have grown dramatically since 1908 when they were first held in London.

item.title: Photos: Olympic outtakes
item.description: Photos: Olympic outtakes

item.title: Olympics: American gold medals
item.description: Olympics: American gold medals

item.title: Star rockers: Free band Pussy Riot
item.description: Music stars including Pete Townshend of The Who, Alex Kapranos of Franz Ferdinand and Corinne Bailey Rae called on Russia to free three members of the punk rock band Pussy Riot, who are on trial in Moscow on hooliganism charges.

item.title: Who was Bulgaria bus bomber?
item.description: Bulgarian police released a composite image Wednesday of the man accused of carrying out a suicide bomb attack on a bus at Burgas airport last month, in which five Israeli tourists and the Bulgarian bus driver died.

item.title: Romney trip: Success or disaster?
item.description: In the estimation of Mitt Romney and his top campaign aides, there were no gaffes, no mistakes, no ill-advised statements on the Republican candidate's overseas trip.

item.title: Politician charged in dissident death
item.description: A Spanish politician is facing a charge of vehicular homicide for the car crash that killed prominent Cuban dissident Oswaldo Paya, Cuba's state press said Tuesday.

item.title: Official resigns after wife's arrest
item.description: The finance minister of Honduras has resigned after police arrested his wife. Authorities said they found a stash of money totaling more than $57,000 in her car.

item.title: Racy video sparks firing of official
item.description: An online video showing a now-former Costa Rican official in her underwear has sparked a debate over the privacy of government workers in the Central American country -- and cost the official her job this week.

item.title: Panetta: Full pressure on Iran
item.description: U.S. Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta met his Israeli counterpart on Wednesday just days after presumptive GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney visited Jerusalem and pledged to support any measures to keep Iran from developing a nuclear bomb.

item.title: Iraq: Deaths at 2-year peak
item.description: Violence in Iraq hit a nearly two-year peak in July, with 325 deaths reported, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

item.title: Fighting for stateless children
item.description: In Jordan and Lebanon, women married to foreigners are taking to the streets to fight for their children's citizenship rights.

item.title: TV channel run by veiled women
item.description: After graduating from the mass communication department of Cairo University, Heba Seraq-Eddin couldn't find a job. Potential employers turned her down, she says, because of her veil. Heba wears the niqab, the black fabric that covers her whole face, except for the eyes.

item.title: Clinton to visit South Sudan
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will this week make her first visit to South Sudan, a nation barely one year old that is locked in a bitter dispute with its northern neighbor, as part of a six-country tour of Africa.

item.title: Uganda tackles Ebola outbreak
item.description: Teams in Uganda are trying to track down anyone who came into contact with patients infected with the Ebola virus, which has killed at least 14 people there this month, authorities said Monday.
